awd_titl_txt: Leveraging Virtual Reality to Connect Learning and Integrate Course Knowledge in the Industrial Engineering Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
Integrated engineering curricula are intended to help students build stronger links across different courses in an engineering program, thereby improving student ability to transfer knowledge between courses. Motivations for offering integrated engineering curricula include improving the ability of first year students to make connections between mathematics and science courses and future courses in engineering, as well as improving student retention in the first and second years. Virtual Reality (VR) is a powerful, immersive interactive computer-generated experience that is fast gaining popularity. The goal of this project is to leverage VR technology to connect concepts taught in different courses across the Industrial Engineering curriculum. Expected outcomes include improving knowledge transfer and retention in Industrial Engineering, furthering the national goal of training more scientists and engineers. 

Significant curriculum integration will be achieved by using holistic VR-based learning modules to facilitate the transfer of knowledge. Modules will be designed to help students understand the inter-relationships between core engineering concepts within the curriculum and the relationships between what they learn in the classroom and real-life applications. The impact of VR-based integrative learning experiences on engineering student learning, motivation, and engineering identity will be examined. The curricular materials that are developed will be freely available and will be disseminated to the engineering education community through workshops and publications. Based on emerging educational research results, the use of VR systems may be particularly effective for women and could contribute to diversifying the engineering field by reducing the gender gap in engineering fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Industrial engineering is a field that deals with designing and improving complex systems, such as manufacturing, logistics, and service systems. However, many students find it hard to see how different courses in the curriculum are related and how they can apply transfer knowledge to real-life problems. To address this challenge, this project proposed a new way of teaching industrial engineering called the Connected Learning and Integrated Course Knowledge (CLICK) approach. The CLICK approach uses virtual systems including virtual reality (VR), simulation-based learning, and nonlinear storytelling, to simulate a manufacturing system that produces power drills. The virtual systems can be used in different courses and they act as a theme or story to connect the concepts from different courses across the Industrial Engineering curriculum. The students use the virtual systems and their corresponding learning modules to collect and analyze data, design and improve processes, conceptualize and evaluate solutions, and understand the impact of their decisions and solutions on the system’s performance.

The virtual systems learning modules were used in several courses across the Industrial Engineering curriculum and covered topics including probability, statistics, and operations research, e.g., queueing theory and inventory models. The team conducted several experiments and collected data in classrooms for two groups: Control and intervention groups. The control group students were taught the concepts traditionally while the intervention group students used the virtual systems and the corresponding learning modules. The collected data involved demographics, experience level in simulation, gaming, and virtual reality, learning outcomes, and survey instruments related to motivation, self-efficacy, and engineering identity. The usability of the learning modules was investigated as well.

The project investigated the effectiveness of the CLICK approach in several courses across the curriculum. In general, the virtual systems learning modules increased the students’ motivation. Different experiments showed a statistically significant increase in one or more constructs related to motivation. Most of the studies showed no statistically significant difference in engineering identity except for one study in which the engineering identity was lower. This result indicated that the learning modules helped students understand the complexity of the industrial engineering job. Therefore, they tended to lower their engineering identity rating on two constructs: Recognition, and interest. In general, the intervention group students reported higher confidence and better self-assessment of their understanding, and good learning outcomes. The grades of the intervention group students were positively correlated with their motivation and engineering identity scores. Another study explored the effectiveness of using the virtual system learning modules outside the classroom versus inside the classroom. The results showed no statistically significant difference between the two groups on any of the measurements, suggesting that the learning modules can be used in any setting without compromising students’ quality of education.

The project helped students understand the “big picture” of how concepts taught in the Industrial Engineering curriculum fit together. Better understanding leads to more persistence and retention as well as better engineering graduates. Two virtual system learning modules were developed and used in several courses across the curriculum. The results of this project provided the foundation for a deeper investigation of the impact of the CLICK approach on student motivation, learning outcomes, engineering identity, and self-assessment of their understanding.
